justification: "Objective poverty (objective economic situation) was measured as equivalized household income (Hagenaars, de Vos, and Asghar Zaidi, 1994)."

measured_by: MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status
justification: "Subjective poverty ... was reflected by 3 indicators, namely, The MacArthur scale of subjective social status (Adler & Stewart, 2007...)."
The authors state that subjective poverty was indicated by "the mean score of the created 6-item scale of financial satisfaction (ω = .92-.93)."
They list as a third indicator "1-item perception of own poverty/wealth."
"Negative affect was assessed by PANAS (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988; ω = .92)."
"The level of perceived stress was measured by the Perceived stress scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983, ω = .81-.86)."
"A digit span test was used to measure working-memory (ω = .81-.86)."
"To measure participants’ self-control, the Self-control scale (Tangney, Baumeister, & Boone, 2004, ω = .75-.81) was used."

"To examine the tendency of intuitive/deliberative thinking, a test of cognitive reflection containing 3 items from the original Cognitive Reflection Test and 3 additional items ... was used (ω = .80-.87)."
"To assess participants’ economic preferences, we employed the Staircase time ... modules, as proposed by Falk et al. (2016)."
"In Study 2, we also administered IMCQ ... as an additional measure of time-discounting."
The same sentence notes that economic preferences were assessed with "Staircase time and risk modules," referring to risk when a reward is involved.
"In the case when risk preference involved a loss, we adopted the Staircase module and reduced the amount of money to half."
"To measure financial literacy, we used 6/8 items proposed by Lusardi (2008; ω = .70-.81)."
